question.text: Two substances $\mathrm{R}$ and $\mathrm{S}$ decompose in solution independently, both following first order kinetics. The rate constant of $\mathrm{R}$ is twice that of $\mathrm{S}$. In an experiment, the solution initially contained 0.5 millimoles of $\mathrm{R}$ and 0.25 of $\mathrm{S}$. The molarities of $\mathrm{R}$ and $\mathrm{S}$ will be equal just at the end of time equal to

solution.text:
Substance $\mathrm{R}$ Substance $\mathrm{S}$ $2 \mathrm{k} \quad \mathrm{k}$ rate constant $\mathrm{t}_{1 / 2}=\mathrm{n} \times \mathrm{t}_{1 / 2}$

where $\mathrm{n}=$ number of half life period

Amount of $\mathrm{R}$ left $=\frac{0.5}{(2)^{\mathrm{T} / \mathrm{t}_{/ 2}}}$

Amount of $\mathrm{S}$ left $=\frac{0.25}{(2)^{\mathrm{T} / 2 \mathrm{t} / 2}}$

Equating both $\frac{0.5}{0.25}=\frac{(2)^{\mathrm{T} / \mathrm{t}_{1 / 2}}}{(2)^{\mathrm{T} / 2 \mathrm{t}_{1 / 2}}}$

or $2=(2)^{\mathrm{T} / \mathrm{t}_{1 / 2}}$

$\therefore \mathrm{T}=2 \mathrm{t}_{1 / 2} \cdot 2 \mathrm{t}_{1 / 2}$ is half life of $\mathrm{S}$ and

twice the half -life of $\mathrm{R}$
